The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the models in the related study was a combination of several metrics, including sensitivity, specificity, True Skill Statistics (TSS), kappa coefficient, area under the curve (AUC), and correlation. instruction: Can the use of Sentinel-2 satellite imagery and spectroscopic methods be considered superior to traditional methods in modeling the distribution of Prosopis juliflora in the lower Awash River basin, Ethiopia?
Output: Yes, the use of Sentinel-2 satellite imagery and spectroscopic methods can be considered superior to traditional methods in modeling the distribution of Prosopis juliflora in the lower Awash River basin, Ethiopia. The study evaluated the performance of six commonly used Species Distribution Models (SDMs) and one ensemble model using Sentinel-2 spectral bands and biophysical variables. The results showed that these models, particularly the Random Forest (RF) algorithm, provided successful predictions with high True Skill Statistics (TSS) and area under the curve (AUC). The study also highlighted the importance of machine learning algorithms and the relative influence of different variables in modeling invasive species distribution. Therefore, the use of Sentinel-2 satellite imagery and spectroscopic methods, combined with machine learning and regression models, has a higher capacity to accurately model the distribution of Prosopis juliflora in the lower Awash River basin.
